title-group.article-title: Cascade anchoring strategy for general mass production of high-loading single-atomic metal-nitrogen catalysts

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Although single-atomically dispersed metal-Nx on carbon support (M-NC) has great potential in heterogeneous catalysis, the scalable synthesis of such single-atom catalysts (SACs) with high-loading metal-Nx is greatly challenging since the loading and single-atomic dispersion have to be balanced at high temperature for forming metal-Nx. Herein, we develop a general cascade anchoring strategy for the mass production of a series of M-NC SACs with a metal loading up to 12.1âwt%. Systematic investigation reveals that the chelation of metal ions, physical isolation of chelate complex upon high loading, and the binding with N-species at elevated temperature are essential to achieving high-loading M-NC SACs. As a demonstration, high-loading Fe-NC SAC shows superior electrocatalytic performance for O2 reduction and Ni-NC SAC exhibits high electrocatalytic activity for CO2 reduction. The strategy paves a universal way to produce stable M-NC SAC with high-density metal-Nx sites for diverse high-performance applications.

Although single atom catalysts (SACs) with high-loading metal-Nx have great potential in heterogeneous catalysis, their scalable synthesis remains challenging. Here, the authors develop a general cascade anchoring strategy for the mass production of a series of metal-Nx SACs with a metal loading up to 12.1âwt%.

custom-meta.meta-value: Science, Humanities and Social Sciences, multidisciplinary
Science, Humanities and Social Sciences, multidisciplinary

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Single-atom catalyst (SAC) has recently emerged as a rising-star in catalysis since it combines the merits of both heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts while bridges the gap between them with unique features. Comparing with heterogeneous catalysts, SAC maximizes the atom utilization and has homogenous active sites with tunable electronic environments for highly catalytic activity or/and selectivity, while simultaneously holds improved stability and excellent recyclability in contrast to homogeneous catalysts1â10. In the past a couple of years, dozens of SACs have been therefore developed for thermocatalytic reaction (such as CO oxidation11,12, waterâgas shift reaction12,13, and methane conversion14), photocatalytic reaction (photocatalytic H2 evolution15 and CO2 reduction16), electrocatalytic reaction (H2 evolution17â19, O2 reduction20â24, CO2 reduction25, and N2 reduction26), as well as organic electrosynthesis27. Controllable preparation of SAC, however, still remains challenging in view of the strong tendency of migration and aggregation of active atoms during either the fabrication or the subsequent application processes. To this end, supporting monodispersed atoms on appropriate support represents the most feasible and effective way to achieve SAC. Until now, several strategies such as using confinement effect, coordination effect, or chemical bonding have been reported to synthesize isolated metal sites over supports by (1) limiting the loading amount of active component; (2) boosting the interactions between metal atom and support; or (3) employing defect or void on support28â32.

Among SACs, atomic metalâNx (MâNx) moieties anchored on carbon support (MâNC) have attracted particular interests especially in electrocatalysis, since nitrogen can not only effectively anchor and stabilize single-metal atom on carbon but also modulate the electronic structures of metal or carbon atom to optimize the adsorption/desorption of intermediates for enhancing catalytic performance33â37. Moreover, carbon supports are readily available for commercial use and highly electrically conductive for accelerating electron transfer during reactions. Such single-atomic MâNC SACs have demonstrated extraordinary promise in catalytic oxidation of benzene to phenol38, chemoselective hydrogenation of nitroarenes to produce azo compounds39, semihydrogenation of 1-hexyne40, etc. Huang and Duan et al.41 recently reported a two-step approach to the synthesis of well-defined atomic MN4C4 (Mâ=âFe, Co, Ni) moieties embedded in graphene with a metal loading of ~0.05 at% as efficient electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction.

The catalytic activity and turnover efficiency of a catalyst and thus the power/energy density of catalyst-based devices closely depend on the number of catalytic sites, besides its intrinsic activity. One of big challenges for SAC is the low concentration of single-atomic sites, since the loading and the aggregation of atoms have to be balanced. Especially at elevated temperature, metal atoms are getting easier to migrate and aggregate, causing more challenging to achieve MâNC SACs with high metal loading since the formation of MâN bonding usually needs high temperature (such as over 700âÂ°C)42â45. Although the progress has been made on the synthesis of MâNC SACs, few reports can achieve the metal loading over 4âwt%. Another challenge is the mass production of MâNC SACs, which is essential to their practical applications. Most strategies for the synthesis of SAC need delicate control of the defects in supports and synthetic procedures to stabilize single atoms, whereas the mass production requires the commercially available low cost supports and scalable, manageable processing. It is therefore highly desirable to develop a method compatible with large-scale production for synthesizing MâNC SACs with high metal loadings.

Herein, we report a general approach to synthesize a wide range of MâNC SACs (Mâ=âMn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Mo, Pt, etc.) with metal loadings up to 12.1âwt% via a cascade anchoring strategy. As shown in Fig.Â 1, the metal ions are first chelated by chelating agent such as glucose here, then anchored onto oxygen-species-rich porous carbon support with high surface area (Step 1). The chelating agent can effectively sequester metal ions (primary protection) and bind to O-rich carbon support via the interaction with O-containing groups. The excessive chelating agent bound to support surface will physically isolate the metal complex (secondary protection). The complex bound carbon is then mixed with melamine as a nitrogen source for subsequent pyrolysis to achieve MâNC SACs. During pyrolysis, the chelated metal complex can further secure metal atoms via the decomposed residues up to certain temperature (~500âÂ°C, Step 2) (tertiary protection), while carbon nitrogen species (CNx) (such as C3N4 etc.) decomposed from melamine at higher temperature (>~600âÂ°C) can subsequently bind with metal atoms to form MâNx moieties (Step 3), taking over the protection and preventing metal atoms from aggregation (quaternary protection). Systematical experiments reveal that such sequential protecting strategy allows for producing wide-ranging MâNC SACs with a high metal loading up to 12.1âwt%, since the chelating interaction can take place between a wide range of metal ions and ligands46,47. Moreover, the carbon support can be low-cost commercial porous carbon; the chelating agents can be low-cost carbohydrates, such as glucose etc.; and the processing is very easy to scale up. In this regard, the present strategy is suitable for the low-cost mass production of MâNC SACs for diverse applications. As a demonstration, FeâNC SAC shows a superior electrocatalytic activity for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in 0.1âM KOH with a half-wave potential of 0.90âV (all potentials areÂ versusÂ to RHE) and a kinetic mass current of 100.7âAâgâ1 at 0.9âV, 50âmV and 65âAâgâ1 higher than that of state-of-the-art commercial Pt/C catalyst, respectively. NiâNC SAC exhibits an excellent electrocatalytic activity for CO2 reduction to CO in terms of a good Faraday efficiency of 89% with a high current density of 30âmAâcmâ2 at â0.85âV.Fig. 1
The cascade anchoring strategy for the synthesis of MâNC SACs. First, chelating agent (glucose) efficiently sequesters metal ions and binds to O-rich carbon support, while excessive glucoses physically isolate glucoseâmetal complexes on carbon substrate. Second, the chelated metal complexes further secure metal atoms via the decomposed residues up to certain temperature. Third, CNx species decomposed from melamine at higher temperature subsequently capture metal atoms to form MâNx moieties and integrate into the pyrolyzed carbon layer

sec.title: Synthesis and structural analysis of FeâNC SAC
sec.p:
Since FeâNC electrocatalysts are particularly interested for ORR to replace precious Pt-based commercial catalysts in fuel cells etc. We first take FeâNC SAC as an example to demonstrate our strategy and its application. FeâNC SAC was prepared in two steps. First, porous carbon (PC) support was ultrasonically dispersed in the solution containing Fe source and glucose (chelating agent). Second, the dried powder was ground with melamine (nitrogen source), followed by pyrolysis at 800âÂ°C to achieve FeâNC SAC. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) image (Fig.Â 2a) shows that PC substrate (prepared by pyrolysis of potassium citrate as presented in the section of Methods) has a three-dimensional honeycomb-like morphology with plenty of macropores in several micrometers, which benefits mass transfer during both synthesis and application processes. X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern (cyan curve in Fig.Â 2b) shows two typical broad peaks at 24.3 and 44.3Â° for the PC substrate. The specific surface area and pore volume are measured to be 1713âm2âgâ1 and 0.75âcm3âgâ1, respectively (Supplementary Fig.Â 1). The pore size distribution analysis indicates most of nanopores centered at 1.3 and 2.0ânm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectrum reveals plenty of O-species (10.05 at%) on the surface of the PC substrate (Supplementary Fig.Â 2). X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopic (EDS)-mapping images show that the elemental O uniformly distributes on whole-carbon sheets (Supplementary Fig.Â 3). These features make such carbon substrate perfect for anchoring glucose-chelated Fe complex. The chelation of Î±-D-glucose and Fe(III) ions to form Î±-D-glucoseâFe(III) complex has been reported in the literatures47,48 and supported by our density functional theory (DFT) calculations (Supplementary Fig.Â 4). After mixing this PC substrate with glucose and Fe source, Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectrum and EDS-mapping images indicate that glucose and glucose-chelated Fe complex cover on whole substrate in view of uniform FTIR signals of OâH and distribution of elemental Fe and O (Supplementary Figs.Â 5 and 6). After pyrolysis at 800âÂ°C for 2âh, no additional XRD peaks are detected except for those from carbon (Fig.Â 2b), implying no formation of crystallized Fe. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images (Fig.Â 2c, d) show that carbon sheet support is covered by flocculent sheet-like structures, which is a typical feature of pyrolyzed carbonaceous materials (glucose). Raman spectra (Supplementary Fig.Â 7) indicate that the ID/IG ratio for FeâNC SAC is slightly higher than carbon substrate (1.3 vs. 1.2, PC substrate here went through the same pyrolysis for Raman recording), agreeing with the formation of the flocculent carbon layer in more disorder as observed in TEM image. No Fe-based particles, which are typically seen in pyrolyzed FeâNC products, are found during TEM observation. XRD and TEM results suggest that Fe may exist in a form of single atom. For clearly revealing the state of Fe, the high-angle annular dark-filed scanning TEM (HAADFâSTEM) was used to acquire the evidence of Fe distribution at atomic resolution. As displayed in Fig.Â 2e and Supplementary Fig.Â 8, a number of bright spots in a single-atom size are clearly observed, which can be safely attributed to Fe atoms in this sample. The average size of spots is 1.04âÂ±â0.35âÃ on a basis of statistical analysis on over 400 bright spots (inset in Supplementary Fig.Â 8a), corroborating these Fe atoms are mainly in single-atomic state. EDS spectrum evidences the existence of elemental C, Fe, and N (Supplementary Fig.Â 9a). Electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) and EDS-mapping images depict the homogenous and uniform distribution of Fe and N in the FeâNC SAC (Fig.Â 2f and Supplementary Figs.Â 9bâf and 10).Fig. 2
Structural characterizations of PC support and FeâNC SAC. a SEM image of PC support. b XRD patterns of PC and FeâNC SAC. c TEM, d, HRTEM, e, HAADFâSTEM images of FeâNC SAC. f HAADFâSTEM image and EELS mapping images of Fe, N, and overlaid Fe and N on FeâNC SAC. Scale bars, 1âÎ¼m (a); 200ânm (c); 20ânm (d); 3ânm (e); 2ânm (f)

sec.title: Atomic structure analysis of FeâNC SAC by XAFS and XPS
sec.p:
Element-selective X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy experiments were further conducted, including the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), which are powerful for determining the coordination environment and chemical state of absorbing centers with high sensitivity. As shown in Fig.Â 3a, X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectrum and the first derivative XANES spectrum of FeâNC SAC are very similar to those of the reference iron phthalocyanine (FePc) which has well-defined FeâN4 coordinated sites49â51, while distinct from those of the metallic Fe foil. This means Fe state in FeâNC SAC should be similar to that in FePc. FigureÂ 3b shows the Fourier transform (FT) k3-weighted EXAFS spectra of Fe k-edge. Comparing with the Fe foil, no apparent peaks (2.20 and 4.42âÃ ) for FeâFe coordination are observed in FeâNC SAC. As expected, FT EXAFS spectrum of FeâNC SAC has a strong peak at 1.50âÃ . In reference to FePc, this peak can be well assigned to FeâN distance where a nitrogen shell surrounds one Fe atom. Wavelet transform (WT) was also used to investigate the Fe K-edge EXAFS oscillations of FeâNC SAC and the references. As shown in Fig.Â 3c, WT analysis of FeâNC SAC shows only one intensity maximum at about 4.5âÃ â1 for FeâNC SAC, which is very close to that in the reference FePc (~4.5âÃ â1), but distinct from the feature of Fe foil (7.0âÃ â1). Combining with above HAADFâSTEM results that all Fe species are atomically dispersed without detectable aggregation, these analyses suggest that Fe in FeâNC SAC exists in a similar state to the reference FePc. For giving further insights into the chemical configuration of Fe, FT EXAFS fittings in R, q, and k spaces were carried out to reveal the structural parameters and evaluate the fitting quality. As shown in Supplementary Figs.Â 11 and 12, all fittings are in good consistency with experimental data. The fitting results give an average coordination number of 4.3 for the first shell (FeâN) and an average FeâN bond length of 1.99âÃ (see more details in Supplementary TableÂ 1).Fig. 3
Atomic structure analysis of FeâNC SAC by XAFS and XPS. a Fe K-edge XANES spectra (inset: first-derivative curves), b Fourier transform of Fe K-edge EXAFS spectra, and c, Wavelet transform of the k3-weighted EXAFS data of FeâNC SAC and reference samples (FePc and Fe foil). d N K-edge NEXAFS spectra and e, deconvoluted N 1s XPS spectra of FeâNC SAC and reference FePc

The chemical environments of N in FeâNC SAC and reference FePc were further investigated by near-edge XAFS (NEXAFS) and XPS technique. The N K-edge NEXAFS spectrum of FeâNC SAC shows three distinct peaks at about 398.8, 399.8, and 401.8âeV (Fig.Â 3d). The peak at 398.8âeV can be assigned to pyridinic state or the state similar to aza-bridge in FePc due to the same energy position. The peak at 399.8âeV shares the identical position with the FeâN bonding in FePc, corroborating the existence of FeâN bonding in FeâNC SAC52,53. The wide peak at 401.8âeV could be assigned to pyrrolic or other nitrogen states according to the literatures54,55. For XPS spectra shown in Fig.Â 3e, the N 1s signal for FeâNC SAC can be deconvoluted into several characteristic peaks. The XPS signals at 398.3, 399.5, 400.4, 400.9, and 401.7âeV are assigned to pyridinic-N, FeâNx, pyrrolic-N, graphitic-N, and oxidized-N, respectively56â58. The peak at 399.5âeV indicates the presence of N in the chemical state similar to FeâNx moiety in FePc.59,60 The high-resolution Fe 2p XPS spectrum (Supplementary Fig.Â 13) indicates that Fe exists in form of iron (II). No clear signal of metallic Fe is detected. These XPS data agree with the existence of FeâNx coordination in FeâNC SAC. Moreover, the NEXAFS spectra of O K-edge (Supplementary Fig.Â 14) for FeâNC SAC shows no distinct features of OâFe bonding which should appear in the region from 529 to 531âeV61, suggesting there is no significant OâFe bonding in our FeâNC SAC. All the above analyses support that FeâN bonding is the dominated Fe state in FeâNC SAC. The amount of Fe in FeâNC SAC is further determined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Supplementary Fig.Â 15). The Fe loading of 8.9âwt% is significantly higher than those in reported SACs (Supplementary TableÂ 2), suggesting the present strategy is able to deliver single-atomic catalysts with a high metal loading. Importantly, it should be noted that this cascade-anchoring strategy can achieve the mass production of FeâNC SAC due to facile and manageable processing. As a demonstration, about 8âg of FeâNC SAC is easily obtained in a one-batch synthesis (Supplementary Fig.Â 16) in the laboratory. XRD pattern and TEM images indicate that the product shares the similar structure to the sample characterized above (Supplementary Fig.Â 17).

sec.title: Insight into the formation process of FeâNC SAC
sec.p:
As mentioned above, the present cascade-anchoring strategy is able to prepare single-atomic FeâNC materials with a high Fe loading up to 8.9âwt%. It is found that the successive protection tactics at each stage during the synthesis are essential to prevent the aggregation of Fe atoms at high loading condition. (1) Glucose chelating effect: The chelation of Fe ion with glucose is the first protection step to well isolate Fe ion in physical space. The control sample (Fe@CâN) prepared in parallel, except for no addition of glucose, shows clearly iron/iron carbide nanoparticles on carbon sheets with some nanotubes formed via Fe-catalyzed growth during the decomposition of melamine, as evidenced by XRD pattern (Fig.Â 4a) and TEM images (Fig.Â 4b and Supplementary Fig.Â 18). The crystallized Fe species are even observed in the sample prepared at 500âÂ°C, without addition of glucose (XRD pattern in Supplementary Fig.Â 19 for control sample Fe@CâN-500). The role of chelation is corroborated by another two control experiments. If inorganic iron salt (iron (III) nitrate) is substituted with iron (III) acetylacetonate (Fe(acac)3), where the strong interaction between Fe ion and acetylacetone excludes the chelation of glucose and Fe ion, plenty of iron carbide nanoparticles are formed instead of isolated Fe atoms as suggested by XRD (Fig.Â 4a) and TEM results (Fig.Â 4c and Supplementary Fig.Â 20). Moreover, if other chelating agent such as ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) is used to replace glucose, XRD, TEM, and EDS-mapping results suggest that the similar FeâNC SAC material is obtained (Fig.Â 4a, d and Supplementary Figs.Â 21 and 22). In view of the low cost, availability and solubility in water for mass production, glucose was used as chelating agents in our experiments. (2) Physical isolation of complex: The physical isolation of Fe centers is also important. The excessive amount of glucose is found to be necessary for achieving single-atomic FeâNx in the final product. The insufficient amount of glucose (such as 5:1 molar ratio of glucose: Fe) cannot keep Fe atoms away enough to prevent their aggregation during high-temperature pyrolysis so that some Fe-based nanoparticles are produced (FeâNCâLow Glu, Supplementary Figs.Â 23 and 24). (3) Carbon substrate: O-rich substrate with a high surface area is critical for the synthesis of high-loading single-atomic FeâNx. Commercial Ketjenblack (KB) with a comparable surface area of 1400âm2âgâ1 can be used to replace PC support (Supplementary Fig.Â 25). XRD pattern in Fig.Â 4a and TEM images in Fig.Â 4e and Supplementary Fig.Â 26 imply that the similar catalyst structure is obtained. It is noted that the acid pre-treatment of KB to create O-rich surface is necessary to achieve uniform distribution of glucoseâFe complex and physically isolate Fe centers on substrate. Without acid treatment, KB is not dispersed well in aqueous solution and Fe aggregates are obtained. In contrast, if graphene oxide (GO) with a low surface area of 90âm2âgâ1 is used (Supplementary Fig.Â 25), a number of Fe-based nanoparticles are produced as evidenced by XRD pattern (Fig.Â 4a) and TEM images (Fig.Â 4f and Supplementary Fig.Â 27). It is believed that such surface area is not sufficient to isolate glucoseâFe complex, leading to the aggregation of active Fe atoms during pyrolysis. (4) Cascade protection at different stages: As mentioned above, excessive glucose to chelate Fe ion and physically isolate them is required to achieve FeâNC SAC; however, it is not sufficient. It is found that the glucose protection is only effective at a moderate temperature. The control sample prepared without addition of melamine shows no crystalline Fe species at the pyrolysis temperature up to 500âÂ°C (Fe@C-Glu-500) (Supplementary Fig.Â 19), whereas increasing the pyrolysis temperature to 600âÂ°C crystallized Fe2O3 phase can be clearly detected in XRD pattern (Fe@C-Glu-600) (Supplementary Fig.Â 19). Further increasing the temperature to 800âÂ°C metallic Fe-based phase shows up in XRD pattern (Fig.Â 4a) of the sample (Fe@C-Glu) instead of Fe2O3 phase due to carbothermal reduction and a number of nanoparticles can be clearly identified in TEM images (Fig.Â 4g and Supplementary Fig.Â 28). Without melamine these nanoparticles can even migrate, leaving the holes in carbon substrate. It is known that melamine decomposes to N-containing species such as C3N4 etc. at over 400âÂ°C62. In the synthesis of FeâNC SAC, when the Feâglucose complexes start to decompose and release Fe atoms at elevated temperature, the surrounding abundant active CNx species decomposed from excessive amount of melamine will instantly capture these active Fe atoms by forming FeâN bonding as FeâNx species since it is an energy-favorable process, similar to the case of the formation of PdâN63. These FeâNx species will be subsequently incorporated into the carbon network newly evolved from the graphitization of glucose and melamine during pyrolysis, preventing them from aggregation. The single-atomically dispersed FeâNx sites have been evidenced by the above-mentioned analyses.Fig. 4
Structural characterizations of control samples. a XRD patterns and bâg, TEM images of Fe@CâN (b), Fe(acac)3âNC (c), FeâNC SACâEDTA (d), FeâNC SACâKB (e), FeâNâGO (f), and Fe@C-Glu (g). Scale bars: 200ânm (b, d); 100ânm (c, e, f); 500ânm (g)

sec.title: Electrocatalytic performance evaluation of FeâNC SAC
sec.p:
As a demonstration of the potential applications of MâNC SACs, the electrocatalytic activity of FeâNC SAC for ORR was evaluated and compared with benchmark Pt/C catalyst and control samples (Fe@CâN, Fe@C-Glu, and CâN-Glu). As shown in Fig.Â 5a and Supplementary TableÂ 3, the state-of-the-art commercial Pt/C (20âwt%) exhibits a good ORR activity in terms of an onset potential (defined by the potential at which the current density reaches 0.1âmAâcmâ2)64,65 of 0.96âV and a half-wave potential of 0.85âV. While the present FeâNC SAC obviously shows a positively shifted onset potential (0.98âV) and a half-wave potential (0.90âV), which are 20 and 50âmV more positive than those for Pt/C catalyst and superior to most of non-precious metal ORR electrocatalysts (Supplementary TableÂ 4). The mass activity of FeâNCâSAC is calculated to be 9.0âAâgâ1 at 0.90âV. What is more, the FeâNC SAC shows a high kinetic mass current of 100.7âAâgâ1 at 0.90âV, 65âAâgâ1 larger than Pt/C (35.7âAâgâ1). In contrast, control sample Fe@CâN (prepared without glucose), Fe@C-Glu (prepared without melamine), and CâNâGlu (prepared without iron) demonstrate poor ORR electrocatalytic activities (Supplementary Fig.Â 29). The superior ORR electrocatalytic activity of FeâNC SAC is further confirmed by the smallest Tafel slope (48 vs. 69âmV decâ1 for Pt/C) (Fig.Â 5b) and the lowest H2O2 yield (below 3.5% at the whole potential range) (Fig.Â 5c). These results indicate that ORR process on FeâNC SAC follows a four-electron pathway with a high electrocatalytic efficiency for ORR.Fig. 5
Evaluation of electrocatalytic performance of FeâNC SAC for ORR. a Steady-state ORR polarization curves of FeâNC SAC, Pt/C and control samples (Fe@CâN and Fe@C-Glu). b Corresponding Tafel plots. c Hydrogen peroxide yield. d Steady-state ORR polarization curves of FeâNC SAC recorded in O2-saturated 0.1âM KOH with or without poisoning by 0.01âM SCNâ, and one collected after removing SCNâ. e Steady-state ORR polarization curves of FeâNC SAC with different Fe loading. f Steady-state ORR polarization curves of FeâNC SAC and Pt/C before and after 5000 potential scanning cycles in O2-saturated 0.1âM KOH

To get insight into the active sites for ORR in FeâNC SAC, additional control experiments were carried out. Although there is still debate about the most active sites for ORR in FeâNâC catalysts due to complicate catalyst structures, FeâNx site is generally considered to play an important role in catalyzing ORR. It has been reported that SCNâ ion is able to strongly interact with Fe center, thus poisoning FeâNx coordination site66. Since the coordination of FeâSCN is stable in the acidic condition but not in the alkaline medium, we first test the ORR activity of FeâNC SAC in O2-saturated 0.1âM HClO4 containing 0.01âM SCNâ. The result shows that the half-wave potential decrease distinctly by about 116âmV comparing with the curve measured without addition of 0.01âM SCNâ (Supplementary Fig.Â 30), which can be ascribed to the blocking of FeâNx active sites by SCNâ. Moreover, when rinsing this pre-poisoned electrode to pHâ=â7 and re-testing it in O2-saturated 0.1âM KOH, the half-wave potential negatively shifts by about 30âmV compared with the values measured in 0.1âM KOH without SCNâ (Fig.Â 5d)67,68. It is noted that polarization curve can gradually recover to its original state during the measurements since the blocked FeâNx coordination sites can be gradually released as the dissociation of FeâSCNâ in KOH (Fig.Â 5d). These results suggest that FeâNx sites should be the most active sites in FeâNC SAC in view that only two possible active sites exist, i.e. FeâNx sites and N-doped carbon. To further demonstrate the role of FeâNx sites, we prepared another control sample FeâNC SAC with a low Fe loading via reducing the amount of Fe source and keeping all other conditions same. The characterizations indicate that the similar catalyst to FeâNC SAC was achieved except for the low Fe loading of 2.6âwt% (vs. 8.9âwt% for FeâNC SAC) (Supplementary Fig.Â 31). The electrochemical measurements show that the ORR electrocatalytic activity is significantly attenuated in terms of 80âmV negatively shifted half-wave potential and decreased limiting current density (Fig.Â 5e). This result corroborates that FeâNx sites in FeâNC SAC are the efficient active sites for delivering a high ORR activity and the loading of FeâNx sites affects the activity. Furthermore, it is noted that FeâNC SAC also shows a better ORR electrocatalytic activity than the reference sample FePc/C which was prepared by loading FePc on carbon substrate with a similar Fe loading (see more details in Supplementary Fig.Â 32). This could be ascribed to the severe aggregation of FePc and the possible differences in the environments of FeâNx centers for our FeâNC SAC and reference FePc/C.

Durability is another important criterion for assessing electrocatalyst performance. The durability of FeâNC SAC was evaluated using accelerated durability test (ADT) by cyclic voltammetry experiment from 0.6 to 1.0âV at 50âmVâsâ1 in O2-saturated 0.1âM KOH. As shown in Fig.Â 5f, polarization curves recorded after 5000 cycles for FeâNC SAC display a negligible degradation for half-wave potential and limiting current density, indicating its superior durability in alkaline medium. TEM and EDS-mapping images reveal that no Fe aggregation is observed, and the atomic dispersion of FeâNx sites retains in FeâNC SAC after ADT (Supplementary Fig.Â 33). By contrast, the commercial Pt/C catalyst shows a 20âmV loss in half-wave potential and appreciable reduction of limiting current density after ADT. The significant activity degradation for Pt/C catalyst should be attributed to the serious dissolution/agglomeration of Pt nanoparticles during ADT, as shown in Supplementary Figs.Â 34 and 3569.

sec.title: Demonstration for general synthesis of MâNC SACs
sec.p:
Inspired by the simplicity and general applicability of the present cascade-protection strategy, we easily extend it to prepare a wide range of other MâNC SACs (Mâ=âMn, Co, Ni, Cu, Mo, Pt, etc.) with a high metal loading. As shown in Fig.Â 6aâf and Supplementary Fig.Â 36, the white spots in a size of single atom in HAADFâSTEM images indicate that Mn, Co, Ni, Cu, Mo, and Pt are single-atomically dispersed in the PC substrate. A couple of spots with different size could be ascribed to the metal atom imaged at different focusing planes or possible atom cluster. XRD patterns prove that no crystallized metal-based phases are detected (Supplementary Fig.Â 37). EDS spectra, corresponding mapping images and EELS-mapping images confirm the existence of element metal and nitrogen as well as their homogenous distribution (Supplementary Figs.Â 38â45). These results suggest that these MâNC SACs should share the similar structure to FeâNC SAC. TGA analyses give the metal loading from 12.1 to 4.5âwt% (Fig.Â 6g and Supplementary Fig.Â 46). The variation could be ascribed to the differences in the interaction of glucose and metal ions as well as the carbon loss in the presence of different metals. The exploration for the applications of these MâNC SACs are expected in view of the high density of single-atomically dispersed metalâNx active centers. For example, NiâNC SAC exhibits the potential for CO2 reduction to CO and shows an 89% of Faraday efficiency at â0.85âV with a 30âmAâcmâ2 of current density for CO (Supplementary Fig.Â 47 and Fig.Â 6h, i). This high current density outperforms most reported Ni-based single-atom catalysts, which should be attributed to the high-density Ni-based active sites with a Ni loading of 5.9âwt% in NiâNC SAC (Supplementary TablesÂ 5 and 6).Fig. 6
Atomic structure characterizations and loading analysis of MâNC SACs. aâf HAADFâSTEM images for MnâNC SAC (a), CoâNC SAC (b), NiâNC SAC (c), CuâNC SAC (d), MoâNC SAC (e), and PtâNC SAC (f). Scale bars, 3ânm (aâf). g Metal loading in MâNC SACs. h Faradaic efficiency of CO, and i, jco for NiâNC SAC and control sample (NC)

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In summary, a cascade-protection strategy is developed to synthesize single-atomic metalâNx sites on N-doped carbon with a high metal loading up to 12.1âwt%. The single-atomic dispersion of metal atoms and the formation of metalâNx sites are evidenced by the different analytic techniques, including HAADFâSTEM, EELS, XANES, EXAFS, and NEXAFS etc. The formation process of single-atomic metalâNx sites and the effectiveness of the cascade-protection strategy are systematically investigated by a series of control experiments. The results suggest that the chelation of glucose and Fe ion, physical isolation of glucoseâFe complex via excessive glucose, support with sufficient O-species and surface area to anchor and isolate glucoseâFe complex, and the binding with N-species at elevated pyrolysis temperature are required to achieve the high-loading single-atomic FeâNx sites. As a demonstration, the electrocatalytic performance of FeâNC SAC for ORR is evaluated. Benefiting from the high-loading FeâNx active sites and their single-atomic dispersion for exposing each site, FeâNC SAC exhibits a superior ORR electrocatalytic activity and durability with a half-wave potential of 0.90âV and a kinetic mass current of 100.7âAâgâ1 at 0.90âV, 50âmV and 65âAâgâ1 higher than state-of-the-art Pt/C, respectively. The poisoning and loading-dependent experiments indicate that such ORR performance should be from FeâNx sites. The mass production and scalability of the present strategy is demonstrated by synthesis over 8âg of such FeâNC SAC with consistent ORR activity in a single-lab batch. The universal syntheses of other MâNC SACs (Mâ=âMn, Co, Ni, Cu, Mo, Pt, etc.) demonstrate that such strategy can be easily adapted to apply different chelating agents, substrates, and metal sources for a wide range of metalâNC SACs. In view of high-loading metalâNx coordination sites in single-atomic level, these materials are expected for diverse applications, including electrocatalysis and heterogeneous catalysis etc.

sec.title: Synthesis of PC support
sec.p: In total, 8âmmol of potassium citrate (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.) was pyrolyzed at 800âÂ°C for 1âh in a tube furnace and Ar atmosphere. The black solid product was washed with H2SO4 solution (0.5âM) (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.) and water (18.2 MÎ©) to remove inorganic impurities. After drying at 60âÂ°C, the PC support was achieved.

sec.title: Synthesis of FeâNC SAC
sec.p: In total, 60âmg of PC, 0.3âmmol of iron (III) nitrate nonahydrate (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.), and 6.7âmmol of Î±-D-glucose (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) were dispersed in 5âmL of ultrapure water, and sonicated for 30âmin to get a homogenous black suspension. The slurries were harvested after washing with water and drying at 60âÂ°C, and then grounded together with melamine (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.) at a mass ratio of 1:5. The obtained powder was placed into a tube furnace and heated to 800âÂ°C under Ar flow (100 sccm). After 2âh of pyrolysis, the black FeâNC SAC was obtained. MâNC SACs (Mâ=âMn, Co, Ni, Cu, Mo, and Pt) were prepared via the same procedures, except for using manganese nitrate hexahydrate (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.), cupric nitrate hemipentahydrate (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.), ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.), and (hydro)chloroplatinic acid (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.) as the metal precursor, respectively.

sec.title: Synthesis of control samples
sec.p: (1) FeâNC SACâEDTA was synthesized in parallel by the same method as that for FeâNC SAC, except for using the same mass amount of EDTA (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.) instead of glucose. Fe(acac)3âNC was prepared in parallel by the same method as that for FeâNC SAC, except for using the same molar amount of Fe(acac)3 (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.) instead of iron (III) nitrate nonahydrate. (2) FeâNC SACâKB and FeâNâGO were prepared in parallel by the same method as that FeâNC SAC except for using the same mass amount of commercial KB (1400âm2âgâ1) (Ketjenblack EC-600JD, Akzo Nobel, Inc.) and GO (90âm2âgâ1) (Nanjing XFNANO Materials Tech. Co.) instead of PC support, respectively. (3) Fe@C-Glu was obtained in parallel by the same synthesis route as that for FeâNC SAC, except for no addition of melamine; the samples pyrolyzed at 500, 600, and 800âÂ°C are designated as Fe@C-Glu-500, Fe@C-Glu-600, and Fe@C-Glu, respectively. (4) Fe@CâN was prepared in parallel by the same synthesis route as that for FeâNC SAC, except for no addition of glucose; the samples pyrolyzed at 500 and 800âÂ°C are designated as Fe@CâN-500 and Fe@CâN, respectively. (5) FeâNCâLow Glu was prepared in parallel by the same method as that FeâNC SAC except for using 1.5âmmol glucose instead of 6.7âmmol glucose. (6) CâNâGlu was prepared in parallel by the same synthesis route as that for FeâNC SAC, except for no addition of iron source. (7) FePc/C was prepared by dispersion 60âmg of PC and 42âmg of FePc (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.) in 5âmL of dimethyl formamide (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.), followed by sonication for 30âmin to get a homogenous black suspension. The product was collected after washing and drying. (8) NC was synthesized in parallel by the same method as that FeâNC SAC, except for no addition of iron source and glucose.

sec.title: A scale-up synthesis of FeâNC SAC
sec.p: The product was prepared in parallel by the same synthesis route as that for FeâNC SAC, except for increasing the amount of carbon substrate, iron (III) nitrate nonahydrate, glucose, and ultrapure water to 5âg, 24.8âmmol, 0.56âM and 420âmL, respectively.

sec.title: Catalyst characterizations
sec.p: XRD patterns were recorded on Regaku D/Max-2500 (Rigaku Co., Japan) diffractometer equipped with a Cu KÎ±1 radiation (Î»â=â1.54056âÃ ). The morphologies were characterized by SEM on S4800 (JEOL, Japan) and TEM on JEM-2100F (JEOL, Japan) equipped with an EDS detector. HAADFâSTEM and EELS mapping observations were carried out on a JEOL ARM200F (JEOL, Japan) STEM operated at 200âkV with cold-filled emission gun and double hexapole Cs correctors (CEOS GmbH, Germany). The attainable spatial resolution defined by the probe-forming objective lens is better than 80 picometers. Nitrogen adsorptionâdesorption isotherms were collected on a Quadrasorb SI-MP system (Quantachrome, USA) at 77âK. The specific surface area was calculated by Brunauer Emmett Teller method. The pore size distribution and pore volume were calculated using DFT method. XPS spectra were recorded on an ESCALab220i-XL electron spectrometer (VG Scientific, UK) using an Al KÎ± radiation. Raman spectra were obtained on Lab-RAM HR Evolution (Horiba Scientific, Japan) with a laser excitation wavelength of 532ânm. FTIR experiments were performed using Thermo Fisher Nicolet iN10 FTIR microscope (Thermo Nicolet Corp., USA). The metal loading was measured via TGA on a Netzsch DSC214 instrument (NETZSCH, Germany) from 40 to 800âÂ°C under air flow with a ramp of 10âÂ°C minâ1. XANES and EXAFS of the Fe K-edges were acquired on the XAFS station of the 14W1 beam line of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility. The fluorescence mode was used to record the X-ray absorption spectra of Fe K-edges. Data were recorded by using a Si (111) double-crystal monochromator. The back-subtracted EXAFS function was converted into k space and weighted by k3 to compensate for the diminishing amplitude due to the decay of the photoelectron wave. The Fourier transforming of the k3-weighted (for Fe) EXAFS data was performed in the range of kâ=â3â12âÃ â1 using a Hanning function window to get the radial distribution function. The NEXAFS spectra were collected at Beamline 8.0 of Advanced Light Source in Lawrence Berkeley National Lab via a total fluorescence yield mode with a probing depth of ~100ânm. The samples were thoroughly outgassed before measurements.

sec.title: Electrochemical measurements. ORR Tests
sec.p: All ORR electrochemical measurements were recorded on a rotating ring-disk electrode rotator (RRDE-3A) (ALS, Japan) by a standard three-electrode cell system connected to an electrochemical workstation (Autolab PGSTAT 302N) (Metrohm, Netherlands) at room temperature. A rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) (4âmm in diameter) with catalytic material acted as the working electrode; and an Ag/AgCl electrode (saturated KCl solution) and a graphite rod were employed for the reference and counter electrode, respectively. The working electrodes were prepared as follows: all non-precious homogeneous ink was formed by mixing 2âmg of catalysts and 800âÂµL of ethanol (Beijing Chemical Reagent Factory) in a glass vial and sonicated for 30âmin. The 30âÂµL of ink and 2âÂµL 0.5âwt% of Nafion solution (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.) were dropped on polished RRDE to get catalysts loading of 600âÂµgâcmâ2 and dried 10âmin in the air. For comparison, commercial JohnsonâMatthey Pt/C (20âwt%) was also measured with loading of 25.5âÂµgPtcmâ2. The accelerated durability tests of FeâNC SAC and commercial Pt/C were performed in the O2-saturated 0.1âM KOH (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.) solution by cycling the catalysts between 0.6 and 1.0âV at 50âmVâsâ1, referring to the protocol from USA Department of Energy. Poisoning experiment for FeâNC SAC was first executed in O2-saturated 0.1âM HClO4 (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.) with addition of 0.01âM NaSCN (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.). The remarkably depression of catalytic activity can be seen. After that, the working electrode with poisoned FeâNC SAC was rinsed thoroughly and measured again in 0.1âM KOH under O2 atmosphere. All ORR measurements were collected at a scan rate of 10âmVâsâ1 at a rotation speed of 1600ârpm. Before each ORR test, the electrolyte was purged with oxygen at least for 30âmin. All non-Pt catalysts were scanned in the N2-saturated electrolyte. The obtained background voltammograms were subtracted from that measured in the O2-saturated electrolyte before each ORR measurement.

sec.title: CO2 reduction tests
sec.p: All electrochemical measurements for CO2 reduction were carried out in a gas-tight cell with two-compartments separated with a Nafion membrane (NafionÂ®115, DuPont, Inc.). A same standard three-electrode cell system as that for ORR was used to collect electrochemical data. In a typical prepared process of the working electrode, 600âÂµL of the mixing ink, which was obtained by dispersing 1âmg catalyst in 30âÂµL 0.5âwt% of Nafion solution and 570âÂµL of ethanol solution, was loaded on two sides of a carbon cloth (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.) with 1âÃâ1âcm2. During the CO2 reduction experiments, all measurements were collected at a scan rate of 10âmVâsâ1 in N2-saturated 0.5âM KHCO3 (Alfa Aesar Co., Ltd.) or CO2-saturated 0.5âM KHCO3 electrolyte. The gas phase composition was analyzed by gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890B, USA) every 1âh. The separated gas products were measured by a thermal conductivity detector (for H2) and a flame ionization detector (for CO).

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: This work was supported by the National Key Project on Basic Research (2015CB932302), National Natural Science Foundation of China (21773263 and 91645123) and the Strategic Priority Research Program of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (XDB12020100).Â This research used resources of the Advanced Light Source, which is a DOE Office of Science User Facility under contract no. DE-AC02-05CH11231. Any opinions, findings, conclusions or recommendations expressed in this work are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Natural Science Foundation of China, Strategic Priority Research Program of the Chinese Academy of Sciences.

sec.title: Author contributions
sec.p: L.Z., Y. Z. and J.S.H. conceived the project. L.Z., L.B.H. and C.H. carried out the synthesis, most of the structural characterizations and electrochemical tests. X.Z.L., Q.H.Z. and L.G. performed the HAADFâSTEM characterizations and EELS experiments. L.J.Z. analyzed the EXAFS and XANES data. Z.Y.W. carried out DFT calculations. J.W. and W.Y. performed NEXFAS experiments. L.J.W. discussed the results and commented on the paper. L.Z., Y. Z. and J.S.H. cowrote the paper. J.S.H. supervised the project.

sec.title: Data availability
sec.p: The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.

sec.title: Competing interests
sec.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
